Hi All,
Based on the "Are TestSuites Useless" thread here, Kevin Bourrillion's 
javadoc solution (JUnit Dynamic Suite Builder) and TCLTest 
functionality, I explored adding selective testcase execution through 
filtering on properties rather than using TestSuites for this.  
I'd like to have it be part of the general release or find out if 
there is other work along the same lines.

The basic idea is you invoke junit with a property string (for example 
-Dfilter=inProgress) and your test class and it would run all the 
tests that pass the filter.  Properties are associated with tests 
using the same "pluggable" pattern currently used to create TestCases. 
 That is, the run method is found dynamically based on the name of the 
TestCase and so are the properties meant to be used as a filter.  
Properties can be associated with all the tests in the TestCase and/or 
the individual test methods.  These are combined and then checked 
against the filter.  

Properties are optional and thus backward compatible with existing 
TestCases. Not including a filter string on the cmd line defaults to 
running all the tests.

Filtering in this manner works well with the TestSetup decorator.  
Remaking suites (running tests using tests.elementAt()), are apt to 
break TestSetup usage. Also, this filtering mechanism could be 
extended to work with picking from a gui list.

See below for an example TestCase and a sample textui run.  Currently, 
skips are reported with failures and errors but this could be 
suppressed.  

I realize adding "skip" to "error" and "failure" complicates an 
otherwise squeaky clean report.  It can be suppressed when there are 
none I suppose.

Comments appreciated.

Kevin Connor Interwoven

Example Test Case: public class IWTest extends FilteredTestCase { 
public final static String fTestCaseFlags = "regression, productA";
    public IWTest(String name)
    { super(name,fTestCaseFlags); }
	public final static String testOneFlags = "slow"; public void 
testOne()
    { assert(false); }
	public final static String testTwoFlags = "knownBug, 
-productA"; public void testTwo()
    { assert(true); }
	public final static String testThreeFlags = "inProgress"; 
public void testThree()
    { assert(true); }
    public void testPlatform()
    { String curPlatform = System.getProperty("os.name");
        System.out.println(curPlatform + "\n");
        if (curPlatform.toLowerCase().startsWith("windows"))
        { skip("This doesn\'t work on windows."); } }
}

Example Run:
java -Dfilter=productA IWTest ..S..S
Time: 0.35
FAILURES!!! Test Results: Run: 4 Failures: 1 Errors: 0 Skips: 2 There 
were 1 failure: 1) testOne(IWTest) 
"junit.framework.AssertionFailedError" There were 2 skips: 1) 
testTwoFlags(IWTest) "Test marked no [productA]" 2) 
testPlatform(IWTest) "This doesn't work on windows."
subject: Test selection (Are TestSuites Useless?)
